When starvation fully sets in, it will harm your Settlement by lowering Happiness and destroying one of its buildings or improvements. Always keep an eye on your Food supply and Settlement Happiness to avoid the consequences of starvation.

Tip: If your City is starving, consider specializing a connected Town to help feed it. If low Happiness is the issue, stationing a high-level Commander in the City can significantly reduce the Unhappiness it generates.
Land and Territory

[BLIST][LI]Owned Tile: A tile within your Settlement’s borders.[LI]Unowned Tile: A tile that is not yet part of any Settlement’s borders.[LI]Improved Tile: A Rural tile with an improvement (worked by a population point).[LI]Unimproved Tile: A Rural tile without an improvement (no population assigned to it).[LI]Friendly Tile: A tile you own, or owned by your allied Civs and City-States.[LI]Neutral Tile: A tile not owned by any Civilization.[LI]Enemy Tile: A tile owned by a Civilization you are at war with.[/LIST]
Tip: A lot of effects function according to these tile types. Make sure to check what type of tile a specific effect mentions when making a decision.
Merchants

Merchants can travel to other leaders’ settlements to establish trade routes, gaining access to their resources. Merchants are also useful in building roads within an empire. Merchants go away after each Age Transition. Make sure to research the corresponding tech/civic to unlock Merchants again after every Age Transition.

In Antiquity and Exploration Age, your Merchants must first move into other Civilizations' borders, before being able to use the create trade route function. There's no such limitation in the Modern Age.

Tip: Merchants are your primary method for acquiring foreign resources. Use them strategically to strengthen your economy and complete certain legacy paths. Additionally, you can use Merchants to build roads within your Empire, which can help you connect Towns to Cities in order to feed them.
Settlement Cap

At a player level, there is a Settlement Cap. This cap is a soft cap that reduces the player's yields when the player goes over that cap. The penalty is 5 Unhappiness per settlement over the cap applied to all Settlements. This is capped at 35. The Unhappiness in turn reduces the yields via its yield reduction effects. The Settlement Cap can be increased via Tech, civic, and attribute trees.
Razed Settlements do not count towards the cap, however, they incur other penalties.
Tip: Staying under the cap is key to maintaining a Happy and Productive empire.
Razing

When a Settlement is captured, the capturer can choose to raze it. Razing a Settlement requires multiple turns to accomplish, and the number of turns correlates to the size (population) of the Settlement. Tiles are razed from the farthest tiles to center.
Razing incurs a -2 influence per age penalty for rest of the age.
Once the process of Razing has started, it cannot be stopped whatsoever. Once a player starts to raze a settlement it cannot be stopped by that player, regardless of diplomatic status.
Tip: Razing is an effective way to stay under the Settlement cap if you decide to go Warmongering. However, be wary of its negative consequences.
Burning Status

Some attacks or effects inflict a Burning status on a tile, dealing a flat 15 damage per turn to any unit standing there. This damage is unaffected by either the attacker’s or defender’s combat strength, and the duration depends on the specific source. For instance, the Burning Arrow unit states a two-turn duration in its description.
Tip: Move units off burning tiles quickly to avoid taking significant damage over multiple turns.
Specialist

Assigning a point of population to an Urban tile creates a Specialist. Specialists amplify the tile's adjacency bonuses and offer benefits like increased Science, Culture, and building adjacency yields (+2 Science, +2 Culture, +0.5 Adjacency Bonus). However, they come with a trade-off, reducing the City’s Food and Happiness by -2 each.
While Towns can acquire Urban tiles by purchasing buildings, only Cities have the ability to gain Specialists, making them unique centers for advancing Science, Culture, and other key yields.
Tip: Strategically place Specialists in high-adjacency Urban tiles to maximize yield boosts. Keep an eye on Food and Happiness, as Specialists can strain resources in rapidly growing Cities.
Ocean Exploration

In Civilization VII, ocean movement varies depending on the type of water tile. Dark blue tiles represent open ocean and function similarly to rough land tiles, consuming all movement points and ending a unit's action until Shipbuilding is researched. Light blue tiles indicate coastal waters, which act like flat land tiles. Units in coastal waters can move and heal using their full movement points.

Units ending their turn on open ocean tiles will take damage due to ocean attrition unless Shipbuilding has been researched. This mechanic adds an element of risk to early ocean exploration, making technological advancements essential for safe passage.
On higher difficulty levels, AI civilizations suffer less damage from ocean attrition, making them more resilient during early exploration.
Research Cartography early to allow your Settlers to cross the ocean. However, your Cog unit can explore the ocean as early as turn 1 of the Exploration Age.
Roads

Roads are automatically created between nearby settlements upon their establishment, allowing for efficient unit movement. Merchants can also be deployed to manually build roads. When a Town is connected to a City via roads, it can support the City by feeding it once it specializes, enhancing the City's growth.
Tip: Use Merchants strategically to establish road connections between key settlements, especially if the automatic road network is insufficient. This will enable better urban growth.
Railroad
Railroads provide fast travel between settlements in Civilization VII, enhancing logistical efficiency across your empire.

To build a railroad, ensure that two settlements are connected by roads and that each has its own Rail Station. Once both Rail Stations are built, the railroad connection is established, allowing for rapid movement between the connected settlements.

Units positioned adjacent to a Rail Station can travel to another Rail Station within 20 tiles in a single turn. This travel consumes all of the unit's movement points for that turn, but it allows for quick relocation across your empire, significantly boosting strategic flexibility.

Strategically place Rail Stations in key settlements to create an efficient transportation network, allowing your units to quickly respond to threats or reinforce distant regions. Rail Station is also a requirement for the Railroad Tycoon Legacy Path.
Religion Overview

Pantheon plays the role of proto-religion the Antiquity Age, players unlock their first Pantheon by researching the Mysticism civic. Pantheons provide unique bonuses often related to natural features and lay the foundation for religious gameplay. Constructing an Altar enables players to benefit from their Pantheon.

Religion becomes available in the Exploration Age. You can start a Religion by completing the Piety Civic and building a Temple. It provides various belief types:[BLIST][LI]Enhancer: the Enhancer belief aids in spreading the player’s religion. Each player may have only one Enhancer belief.[LI]Reliquary: This belief type allows players to earn Relics, which can be displayed for bonuses. Players may have only one Reliquary Belief.[LI]Founder: Awarded initially upon founding a religion, with two additional Founder beliefs awarded later, for a maximum of three. Founder beliefs offer yields and other benefits for converting foreign settlements, incentivizing active religious spread.[/LIST]
A Holy City is the birthplace of a player's religion. This city serves as a stronghold for the player’s chosen faith.
Converting most settlements to your religion requires 2 Missionary charges. However, if the settlement has zero rural population or is being converted for the first time, only 1 charge is needed.
Tip: Focus on settlements with no existing religious influence to maximize your Missionary charges and establish a strong religious presence early.
Religious Gameplay

Missionaries only spread their founder’s religion, and opponents’ Holy Cities CAN be converted to your religion. Independent Peoples cannot adopt a religion until they become City-States. Additional Founder Beliefs are extremely rare and often triggered by random events. There are two Religion flags on the City banner of each Settlement affected by Religion. Both flags need to match, in order for the Settlement to be considered as converted. One flag represents Urban religion, while the other flag represents Rural religion.

Tip: Being the first to spread Religion to a Settlement converts both flags at the same time. If a Settlement already has a Religion, you will need to convert an Urban tile and a Rural tile to accomplish the conversion.
Bankruptcy

If your gold income is negative, you risk bankruptcy. When the treasury balance falls below zero while your income is negative, units with the highest maintenance costs will disband one by one until the balance is restored. This can severely impact military and economic stability, so maintaining a positive income is essential.
Tip: Keep an eye on maintenance costs when expanding your military or building new structures. Avoiding bankruptcy is crucial for sustained growth and security.
Connected Settlements

Connected Settlements facilitate resource and food management between Cities and Towns. There are two types of connections:[BLIST][LI]Trade Connections: Settlements within trade range can freely move resources between them. This connection is ideal for distributing resources across the empire.[LI]Road and Sea Connections: Settlements are linked directly by roads or are both coastal and on the same continent. Towns connected to Cities this way can feed those Cities when selecting a Town Focus.[/LIST]
Tip: Establish trade and road connections early to optimize resource movement and enable Towns to support City growth.
Just One More Turn

Just One More Turn mode allows you to continue your game beyond victory, giving you the freedom to keep exploring, building, and shaping the world even after your story officially concludes. Whether you want to admire your accomplishments, further develop your empire, or simply enjoy the gameplay without pressure, Just One More Turn lets you extend the experience at your leisure.
After you reach the end of the final age, you'll see the "Just One More Turn" option alongside your victory summary. Selecting it keeps your game running, allowing you to resume play right away.
In this mode, you've already won, so additional victories won't end your game, though you can still complete legacy paths and enjoy their special cinematics and achievements.

Tip: You'll always know you're in Just One More Turn mode thanks to a persistent reminder at the top left of your screen. When you're finally ready to conclude your adventure, simply exit to the main menu. There's always one more turn waiting for you if you want it!
Force-Ending Turns (PC-Only)

By pressing Shift + Enter on PC, you can ignore all turn-blocking notifications and immediately end your turn. Please keep in mind that this practice is mostly used when you are stuck, and it’s often controversial in multiplayer due to potential exploits.
Tip: Avoid using this mechanic if playing competitively.
Team Play
In Multiplayer, players can form teams. To set this up, players should select the same team in the team dropdown menu when creating a multiplayer game.

When playing on a team, teammates are locked into an Alliance that cannot be broken and are locked at the max Relationship level. Unlike a standard Alliance, teammates share map visibility. Teammates may use Diplomatic Actions with one another but are prohibited from using Espionage Actions.

Teammates share a Relationship status, and a War and Alliance status, with all other players and teams. When negotiating peace, one player from each team will manage the negotiations. Once a deal is reached, all other players on each team will make peace automatically with no further exchanges.
If one player on a team achieves a Victory, all teammates share in the Victory. If there is a Score Victory, the total Legacy Point count for all teammates are combined for their score.
Note: Technology and Civic progress, and Legacy Path progress, is [B]not[/B] shared between teammates.
Legends System

The [B]Legends[/B] system is Civilization VII's meta-progression framework, tracking your accomplishments across all your games. It recognizes your feats and turns your cumulative successes into lasting rewards. Through this system, each game adds to your achievements, unlocking both cosmetic customizations and gameplay-enhancing items known as [B]Mementos[/B].

Legends consist of four interconnected parts: Legend Challenges, Legend Paths, Legend XP, and Mementos. Together, they ensure that every game matters, encouraging diverse strategies and rewarding consistent play. Whether you win, lose, or try something entirely new, you steadily build toward something bigger than any single match.

Tip: Treat Legends as a rewarding extra layer rather than a mandatory system. Play your way, experiment freely, and you'll naturally find yourself unlocking bonuses and enhancing your civilization’s long-term capabilities.
Legends XP

Legend XP is the currency that drives progression within the Legends system, gained exclusively by completing Legend Challenges. Each completed challenge awards a certain amount of XP toward its corresponding Legend Path: Foundation Challenges reward XP for your global Foundation Path, while Leader Challenges boost specific Leader Paths.

The amount of XP earned depends on a challenge's complexity. Crucially, this XP accumulates even if you lose the game, meaning every match contributes to your overall Legends progression, win or lose. There's no shortcut—only gameplay accomplishments earn Legend XP, making each achievement feel valuable.
Tip: Don’t abandon tough matches early. Completing a few extra challenges can still provide valuable Legend XP, making your efforts worthwhile even in defeat.
Legend Challenges

Legend Challenges are special objectives you can complete while playing Civilization VII. These tasks act like quests or achievements, offering clear goals that range from simple feats like constructing your first Wonder to ambitious achievements such as dominating a victory type. Challenges come in two forms: Foundation Challenges, which can be completed with any leader, and Leader Challenges, unique to specific leaders and their abilities.

Whenever you fulfill the conditions of a challenge, you immediately earn Legend XP. This XP advances your Legend Paths, making each completed challenge meaningful—even if your current match isn’t going well. You can easily track your ongoing and completed challenges through the Challenge Log, helping you target goals aligned with your strategy.
Tip: Regularly check your Challenges Log. Completing even a few objectives can turn a losing game into progress for your long-term Legend growth.
Legend Paths
Basics

Legend Paths represent your overall advancement within Civilization VII's Legends system. They function like experience tracks, leveling up as you earn Legend XP by completing Legend Challenges. There are two main types: the universal [B]Foundation Path[/B] and specialized [B]Leader Paths[/B] specific to each leader.
Balance your efforts between different paths to maximize your long-term benefits. The Foundation Path offers broad rewards, while Leader Paths grant specialized advantages.
Foundation Path

The Foundation Path tracks your progress across all your games, regardless of leader choice. It has 50 levels, each unlocking various rewards, such as cosmetic profile upgrades (badges, banners, titles) and powerful gameplay bonuses called [B]Mementos[/B]. Importantly, leveling this path also unlocks [B]Memento Slots[/B], essential for equipping these bonuses.
Prioritize early levels in your Foundation Path to quickly unlock your first Memento Slots, significantly enhancing your gameplay options.
Leader Path

Each leader in Civilization VII has their own unique Leader Path, which levels up through Leader Challenges specific to their abilities and history. Leader Paths go up to level 10, offering leader-themed Mementos, cosmetic items, and special gameplay advantages tailored to their playstyle.

Tip: Experiment with different leaders regularly to unlock a diverse set of Leader Path rewards. Mementoes unlocked for one leader can be used with any other leaders as well. Pairing specialized mementoes with their respective leaders can often unlock powerful synergies.
Mementos
Basics

Mementos are special items earned from your Legends progression, which can be equipped before each game to provide unique in-game bonuses. They function like gear for your leader, giving effects ranging from basic stat boosts to situational advantages. Every leader can equip up to two Mementos, offering powerful strategic flexibility.

Carefully choose your Mementos before starting a game, matching them to your desired victory type or compensating for your leader's weaknesses. [B]Keep in mind that Mementos can also be swapped between Ages.[/B]
Unlocking and Collection

You unlock Mementos by reaching specific milestones within your Legend Paths. Some Mementos come from higher Foundation Path levels, while many are leader-specific rewards earned by progressing through Leader Paths. Once unlocked, they permanently join your collection and can be freely equipped by any leader.
Unlocking a variety of Mementos by playing multiple leaders can significantly broaden your strategic options, even if you later return to your favorite leader.
Strategies and Synergies

The variety of nearly 100 unique Mementos allows for extensive strategic combinations. Some offer straightforward bonuses, such as extra Economic or Cultural points at game start, while others trigger situationally, like spawning free units after successful espionage actions. Cleverly combining Mementos can lead to powerful or unique strategies, amplifying your strengths or mitigating weaknesses.
Tip: Experiment with different Memento combinations to discover powerful synergies. An unexpected pairing might provide just the advantage you need for your chosen victory path.
